newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila steps further from debt restructuring.
newsitem.headline: Manila steps further from debt restructuring.

text.p: The Philippines took another step away from its debt restructuring status on Monday by retiring part of its Brady bonds in exchange for new, uncollateralised debt issues, finance officials said.
The Brady bonds are restructured Philippine government commercial paper issued in late 1992 when it was not in a position to pay its debts.

The government from Monday is offering two new uncollateralised bonds in exchange for $1.9 billion worth of U.S. Treasury note-backed Brady bonds, otherwise known as par bonds, through a series of auctions, finance secretary Roberto de Ocampo said.
The exchange of the 25- and 26-year Brady bonds will be made through a Dutch auction in which bondholders will submit a minimum rate they will accept for the new 15-year and 20-year bonds.
The government will peg acceptable rates at the end of the offer period, which runs until September 20, as coupon rates for the 15-year floating rate note and 20- year fixed rate note.
Secondary prices of Philippine par bonds inched up slightly on Monday to 81.75 from 81.50 posted last Friday, traders said.
De Ocampo said the effective retirement of the par bonds was part of the government's shift out of higher-yielding debt issues to commercial rated issues such as the Eurobond and Samurai bond issues.

Brady bonds are named after former U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady who in 1989 proposed the concept of bonds backed by the U.S. Treasury but with repayments being made by a sovereign lesser developed country.
Eurobonds are issued in a specific currency outside the currency's domicile. Samurais are issued in Japan by a foreign borrower and denominated in yen.
"All these initiatives distance us further from the era of debt restructuring," de Ocampo said during the launch of the bond exchange programme.
He said the new bonds, which have 100 percent Philippine risk exposure, would also set the benchmarks for local government and private firms as they tap the international debt market.

"Offering investors a long-term bond with uncollateralised Philippine risk will allow a long-term pricing benchmark to be set, which in turn should help government agencies, corporates, and infrastructure projects access long-term maturities at attractive terms," he added.
"Overall, this should reduce reliance on short-term foreign debt."
Central Bank governor Gabriel Singson said the new bonds, which are expected to yield lower rates, will make debt payment easier for the government.
The ratio of external debt servicing cost to current account receipts fell to only 13 percent last year from 36 percent in 1985 after a debt reduction and debt restructuring programme.
J.P. Morgan Securities, the arranger of the new debt issues, said the debt exchange was a "win-win" situation.
"The bond holders (will) increase realisable spread on their investments, though with a commensurate increase in sovereign exposure," it said.
Bond traders said the new programme might spur another round of credit upgrading for Philippine sovereign bonds.
In February, Moody's Investors Services upgraded the country's long-term foreign currency loan to Ba2 from Ba3, while the Standard and Poor's Ratings Group improved its rating to BB from BB minus.
